The disease took a heavy toll of life in the early part of t he century with an estimated 12 5lakhshuman deaths in the last pandemic, which started in 1889 and involved widely scattered areas in the country. There was a decline in the incidence of disease in early fifties and last human case of plague was reported in 1966 from Mulbagal, Kolar district in Karnataka. However, outbreaks of suspected Plague occurred in some parts of the country viz. Attibele, Dharampuri at South India trijunction of Tamil Nadu in May 1984 and at Tangnu village of Him achal Pradesh during September 1983, butY. pestiscouldnotbe isolated to establish the diagnosis of plague. Human plague again struck the country after a lapse of 28 years when in August 1994 cases of bubonic plague were reported from Mamla village of Beed district in Maharashtra and of pneumonic plague from Surat in Gujarat in September 1994. Subsequently, suspected cases of pneumonic plague were reported from Delhi, Varanasi, Karnataka and other states. A total of 876 cases and 54 deaths wre reported. After a gap of 8 years an outbreak of pneumonic plague occurred in Himachal Pradesh with 16 cases & 4 deaths. A localized outbreak of bubonic plag ue was reported from Uttarakhand in 2004 with 8 cases & 3 deaths. N CDCis monitoring the surveillance of pl ague in south India trijunction, Maharashtr a, Gujarat, H.P. and Uttarakhand . 5.2EPIDEMIOLOGY Plague is an acute, onsetdisease caused by Yersinia pestis which is transmitted to man by the bite of infected rat flea. It is primarily a zoonoses being a dis ease of rodents . Man is affected incidentally. 5.2.1Vector Fleas are the natural vectors of plague in the world. Nearly 132 species of fleas all over the world have been incriminated as vectors of plague. In India, the fleas considered important for pla gue transmission are Xenopsylla cheopis, X astia andX brasiliensis. Out of these X cheopis is the principal vector. 5.2.2Reservoirs A large number of mammals may be infected with Y.pestis. More than 200 animals have been incriminated so far. Dogs may b ecome infected without showing any sign of illness and act as sentinel animals. Serotesting of their blood can be an indicator to assess the prevalence of plague in that area. Cats, pigs, cattle, sheep, goat have been infected experimentally. Rodents are t he true natural hosts of Y.pestis. At least 220 species of rodents which inhabit mountains, plains, deserts, cultivated fields and forests in both temperate and tropical climate are known to be infected with plague bacillus. Tatera indica among the wild ro dents and R.norvegicus and R.rattus among the commensal rodents are found to play an important role as reservoir of Y. pestis.45 Fig5.1:General Flea Life Cycle (available at: http://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/fleas/ ) The epidemiology of plague is extremely complex. Infection depends upon its maintenance on a great variety of rodents and insects which differ from country to country and from time to time. Ecological studies point to a multiplicity of factors concerned i n the fluctuating balance that exists between rodents of greater and lesser degree of susceptibility to the plague bacillus and in the degree of r isk to which man is exposed. Plague exists in two forms. 5.2.3Sylvatic Plague The sylvatic plague is mainta ined in relatively resistant hosts called permanent reservoir hosts. These transmit the infection to less resistant animal hosts resulting in epizootics. When infection is endemic in sylvatic rodents, it may remain smoldering for a long time before circums tances favour its epidemic spread. During this time human beings in villages may occasionally contract the disease through handling of an infected animal. The disease does not become epidemic in man unless infection spreads to what is sometimes termed as ' liasion rodent, namely a species of rat that comes in contact with man. 5.2.4Domestic plague Domestic plague isintimately associated with man and rodents living with man . Itoccurs when infection is picked up from permanent reservoir hosts by semidomest ic rodents which i n turn transmit it to the commensal rodents and then to man. The ratfall is the harbinger of domestic46rodent plague and a sign of imminent outbreak of epidemic bubonic plague in man. Rodents are also known to transmit the infection to rem ote areas causing pandemics. 5.3CAUSATIVE AGENT Plague is caused by Yersinia pestis. The organism was discovered in 1894 in Hong Kong by Yersin and Kitasato. It is a short, thick cocco -bacillus measuring 1.5 -2 x 0.5-0.7 microns in size. It has rounded ends, which on staining give a characteristic bipolar appearance to the organism. It is Gram negative, nonmotile and non -sporing. True capsules are seen in living tissues but are less readily seen in culture. The optimum temperature for growth is 2 80Cbutat this temperature, capsular material (envelope substance) is not well developed. For that, the organism should be grown at 37°C . The capsular material is important for antigenicity and protectivity and is used for preparation of Fraction I antigen for se rological test and preparation of plague vaccine. The organism is pathogenic to common laboratory animals like rats, mice, guinea pigs etc. The inoculated animal dies in 3 -4 days time. Necropsy findings reveal marked local inflammation at the site of inoc ulation with enlarged and congested lymphnodes and may show greyish white patches in the tissue. The characteristic coccobacilli are seen in large numbers in films made from local lesions, lymph nodes, spleen pulp and heart blood. 5.4CLINICAL FEATURES IN MAN The incubation period of bubonic plague is 2 -6 days while that of pneumonic plague is 2 -4 days or may be shorter . Bubonic plague This is the commonest form characterised by high fever, toxemia and painful enlargement of lymph glands, which are calle d buboes. Buboes may appear commonly in the groin or in the axillary or cervical region depending upon the site of entry of the organism. The glands gradually become soft and suppurate, and there is marked haemorrhagic tendency with variable septicemia. Mortality is 25 -30% in untreated cases. Pneumonic plague It is due to droplet infection. It is a severe form of disease with high fever and cough with blood tinged tenacious sputum. The disease is highly contagious resulting in explosive outbreaks. Recovery is rare, and death occurs within 2 -4 days. Septicemic plague It is a variant of bubonic plague where there is overwhelming septicemia overrunning the lymph nodes. Consequently, lymph node enlargement is not prominent but the patient is highly toxic. Thisform also results in a very high mortality.47Pestis minor It is an ambulant plague, a mild form of the disease with fever and buboes which may suppurate. Symptoms are very mild so that the patient does not go to bed. 5 .5SIGNS IN RODENTS In rodents dying of plague, necropsy reveals enlargement of lymph nodes with periglandular inflammation and edema that is more frequent in the cervical lymph nodes due to tendency of the rat flea to bite at the neck region. There is pleural effusion, enlargement of spleen with small white areas in the pulp, liver is congested and mottled, congestion and hemorrhages under the skin and in internal organs. Y. Pestiscan be demonstrated in material obtained from these organs. Plague in other animals Besides rodents, pla gue can affect other animals too. Domestic animals, rabbits, camels etc., are all susceptible to infection 5.6 LABORATORY DIAGNOSIS The laboratory diagnosis of plague must be rapid because of the risk for contact and conclusive because of the fear this disease evokes in people and authorities. When plague is suspected, clinical specimen should be collected urgently and specific antimicrobial treatment begun without waiting for laboratory report. Specimen for Diagnosis Material for laboratory diagnosis o f plague can be obtained from the following sources: Human beings suffering from infection Post-mortem specimen Specimen from rodents Flea specimen Soil specimen Human Specimen Appropriate specimen should be examined for evidence of plague if a person re sides in, or has a recent travel history to a plague -infected area; and presents with symptoms suggestive of plague (fever, sepsis syndrome, lymphadenopathy and/or acute pneumonitis). Specimen should be obtained from appropriate sites for isolating the bac teria. As far as possible these should be collected before initiation of antimicrobial therapy.48Laboratory specimen required for Y.pestis are shown from lymph node Lungs Bone Marrow 5.6.1Collection of material The preferred specimen for microscopic examination and isolation from a bubonic case is aspirated fluid from the affected bubo, which should contain numerous organisms. Blood cultures should be taken whenever possible. Organisms may be seen in blood smears if the patient is septicemic. Bacteria may be intermittently released from affected lymph nodes into the blood streams. Theref ore, a series of blood specimen taken 10 -20/30 minutes apart may be productive in the isolation of Y.pestis. Sputum/throat swabs taken from pneumonic plague patients may contain too many other organisms so wayson stain is the test of diagnostic value; the se smears should be examined with more specific direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) test also. Preferably, a bronchial/tracheal washing should be taken from pneumonic plague patient for culture. In biopsies or in specimen taken after post -mortem where recove ry of live organisms is difficult, lymphoid tissue, lung and bone marrow samples may yield evidence of plague infection by DFA test or by detection of Y.pestis by PCT test. Rodent and Flea Specimen Appropriate tissues should be taken from animals for dete ction of Y.pestis. Lymphoid tissues - liver, spleen, lymph nodes -should be removed to test for the presence of F -1 antigen by DFA test. Attempts to recovery Y.pestis should be made by culture of the tissue and by inoculation into susceptible laboratory mice. Bone marrow from dissected animal carcasses may yield positive results when other tissue are not available. Serum and blood specimen may be taken for detection of antibody. Flea should be indentified and placed in pools by species. A flea pool is then tr iturated and inoculated into the laboratory mice for isolation of plague bacteria. In case where no cultutes or serum specimen are available for testing both animal and flea material may be tested by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to detect plague DNA in the specimen.495.6.2Packaging and transportation of Specimen Packaging The etiological agent of plague Yersinia pestis is classified as biosafety Class II agent. The requirement for this class of infectious material, in brief, are: A water-tight prim ary receptacle A water-tight secondary receptacle An absorbent material, which must be placed between the primary receptacle and the secondary packaging. The absorbing material must be adequate to absorb the entire contents of all primary receptacles. Outer packaging must be at least 100 mm in the smallest overall external dimension Itemized list of contents must be enclosed Outside package must be marked with identification of the infectious substance, volume of contents name and telephone number of send er. All materials should be double packed in crush -proof and leak proof containers. Infectious agents, serum or culture vessels should be labeled with alcohol -resistant, permanent ink marker as to the contents and dated. The materials should be sealed wit h para film or tape to prevent inadvertent leakage and then wrapped materials are placed in a leak proof bag, soaked with disinfectant and sealed. The sealed bag is then placed in the first of two crush -proof containers, sealed and placed into the second c rush proof container. Depending on the specimen and the destination, the double container is sent in a sealed box with or without coolant. Do not use wet ice for packaging, because it melts and leaks. Cool packs are acceptable but must be placed in a box so that, upon thawing they do not permit movement of materials within the box. Containers must be especially well sealed if they are being shipped under dry ice conditions. Dry ice evaporates, thus when packing, this must be taken into consideration. Local Surface Transport Examples include transport of specimen from a doctor's office/clinic to a laboratory, from a hospital to a diagnostic laboratory and from one laboratory to another. A hospital, a laboratory, a health service or other approved agency or organization may operate such courier services. The principle of safe transport by this means is the same as for air or international transport -the material should not have any possibility of escaping from the package under normal conditions of transpo rt. The following practices should be observed: Specimen containers should be watertight and leakproof; If the specimen container is a tube, it must be tightly capped and placed in a rack to maintain it in an upright position; Specimen containers and rack s should be placed in robust, leak -proof plastic or metal transport boxes with secure, tight fitting covers; The transport box should be secured in a transport vehicle. Each transport box should be labelled appropriately consistent with its contents Specimen data forms and identification data should be accompany each transport box. A spill kit containing absorbent material, a chlorine disinfectant, a leak proof waste disposal container and heavy duty reusable gloves should be kept in transport vehicle.505.6.3laboratory criteria for diagnosis SuspectedPlague 1.Clinical symptoms that are compatible with plague,e.g. fever, sepsis syndrome, lymphadenopathy and/or acute pneumonitis in a person who resides in or recently travelled to a plague endemic area. 2.If gramnegative and/or bipolar -staining coccobacilli are seen on a smear taken from affected tissues, e.g. Bubo(bubonic plague) Blood(septicemic plague) Tracheal/ lung aspirate (Pneumonic plague). Presumptive Plague Y.pestis F1 antigen detected in clinical mat erials by direct fluorescent antibody testing, or by some other standardized antigen detection method; or Isolate from clinical specimen demonstrates biochemical reactions consistent with Y.pestis or PCR positivity; or A single serum specimen is found posi tive for diagnostic levels of antibodies to Y.pestis F1 Antigen, not explainable on the basis of prior infection or immunization. Confirmed Plague Isolate indentified as Y.pestis by phage lysis of cultures; or A significant (equal or more than 4 -fold) change in antibody titre to the F1 antigen in paired serum specimen. Specimen submitted to the laboratory are processed, in general, for isolation, identification and confirmation as per the flow chart. A smear is prepared and stained. Specimen are directly cultured and/or inoculated in laboratory mice, isolates recovered from mice and culture are further processed for identification. 5.6.4Test Procedures 5.6.4.1Smear Examination The diagnostic value of smears is considerable. During epidemics or epizootics , it is often possible to arrive at a preliminary diagnosis by the examination of smears that show the presence51Fig.5.2Chart for laboratory investigation of characteristic bipola r stained plague bacilli. The smears of clinical material should be prepared as early as possible after collection. Delay in preparation of smears from specimen in transport medium etc. may be result in change in the classical morphology of the bacilli. Sm ears may be prepared from bubo aspirates, spleen, liver blood, sputum and culture isolates. For the fixation of the smear, alcohol should be used preferably because it promotes good bipolar staining of the organisms and kills the bacteria. The staining of the smears can be done by Gram stain, Wayson stain or Direct Flourescent Antibody((DFA) stain. Gram Stain Prepare a thin smear from the specimen on the side. Heat fix the smear by passing the slide quickly through a flame Cover the smear with crystal violet for 1 minute, followed by iodine for 2 minutes. Rinse off with tap water. Decolorise the smear with acetone for 30 seconds, rinse with tap water.(Sheep Blood agar, Braind Hearth Infusion) Colony MorphologyPassive Haemagglutination and PHI test Gram stain Direct fluorescent antibocy test Bio Chemical profileWayson stain Phage TestPCR and DNA Animal InoculationDetection of Animal Pathogenicity Antimicrobial Susceptibility Test52Counterstain the smear with saffranin for 30 seconds, rinse with tap water. Air dry and examine the sm ear using oil immersion. Interpretation The presence of 1.0 -2.0µm X 0.5µm fat, gram negative(pink) and perhaps bipolar staining bacilli seen mostly as single cells or short chains along with clinical symptoms compatible with plague suggest that specimen m ay contain plague bacilli. Quality Control Gramstaining to test specimen should be carried out with parallel staining of known gram positive (Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus subtilis) and gram negative (Esch.coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae) organisms to ensu re proper staining results. Wasyson stain Prepare a thin smear or impression touch preparation on a slide. Let it dry. Fix the smear in absolute methanol for a minimum of 3 minutes. Let the methanol evaporate completely. Flood the smear with Wayson stain for only 5 -10 seconds. Wash the slide with tap water. Let the stained smear air dry. Examine under oil immersion. Interpretation Bipolar stained safety pin fat bacillus is characteristics of Yersinina pestis. All Yersinia pestis may stain as bipolar cell s, but all bipolar staining cells are not Y.pestis. When stained smear reveals the cells with the characteristics safety pin morphology, further evaluation by more specific staining by DFA, culture isolation and identification must follow. Quality Control Yersinia spp. (bipolar staining) and Esch. Coli or B. subtilis(non bipolar staining) cells should be stained to assist interpretation of bipolar characteristics . 5.6.4.2Direct Fluorescent antibody Staining(DFA) Prepare thin tissue (spleen and liver) im pression smears, lymph node aspirate, blood or culture on the slide. Let the smear air dry. Heat fix the smear by passing the slide through flame, cool, then mark the smear area with wax pencil. Add 20µl of conjugate to the heat fixed smear and incubate fo r 30 minutes at ambient room temperature. Cover the slide to prevent evaporation of the conjugate. Soak the slide in Phosphate Buffered Saline(PBS) (pH 7.2 -7.4) for 10 minutes. Discard the PBS from the container and refill with fresh PBS. Soak the slide fo r 10 more minutes. Remove the slide from PBS and air dry. The slide may be examined directly under a fluorescent microscope. Alternatively, in case of UV microscope light source, add a drop of mounting fluid( PBS+glycerol), place a cover lip on top and exa mine the slide.53Interpretation The positive slide will be seen as bright, intense green staining aro und the bacterial cell . If clinical specimens are from patients who have received antibiotic therapy, or if the specimen have not been preserved properly, fluorescence may be seen as small green spots of fragmented F-1 antigen. Because DFA positively is only a presumptive diagnosis for the presence of Y.pestis, attempts should be made to isolate the organism. 5.6.4.3Isolation and Identification of Y.pestis For isolation all clinical specimen, rodent organs, tissues recovered from inoculated mice are streaked onto two 6 percent sheep blood agar (SBA), BIN agar plates for incubation at 280C and 370C for at least 24 -48 hours. Examine the plates for characteri stic colonies. After completion of work decontaminate the plates by autoclaving before discarding the contents. Interpretation Y. pestis grows as grey white, translucent colonies, usually too smart to be seen as individual colonies at 24 hours. After incu bation for 48 hours, colonies are 1 -2mm in diameter, grayish white to slightly yellow colour and more opaque. Under 4x enlargement, after 48 -72 hours the colonies have a raised, irregular, "fried egg" morphology. Colonies also can be described as having "h ammered copper" shiny surface. There is no haemolysis of the sheep RBCs. The growth on SBA should be examined by DFA test, biochemical reactions and bateriophage lysis test for confirmation as Y.pestis. Quality Control Each batch of plates must be checked for sterility by incubating plates at 370C for 24 hours. Each batch of plates must be checked to ensure that it supports the growth of the bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus, Esch.coli and K.pneumoniae. 5.6.4.4Mouse Inoculation Laboratory mice inocula tion has proven to be useful method in the recovery of plague bacilli from other contaminating agents especially if the submitted material are thought to be contaminated with other organisms or are compromised because of deterioration. Procedure A fluid suspension of the inoculum is prepared in saline. Tissue samples are prepared by grinding small pieces (0.5cm2) into a mortar with a few drops of saline. Cultures only need to be suspected in saline and mixed prior to inoculation. Inject 0.1 -0.5ml of suspen sion subcutaneously in the lower abdomen. Two mice are injected with 0.1ml of prepared inoculums from culture of purified material. Whereas for tissue upto 0.5ml of suspension should be injected. For extremely contaminated specimen percutaneous inoculation is recommended. Mice are labelled and placed in cages with sufficient food and water. Mice are checked twice for signs of illness or death. Surviving mice are kept for 3 weeks. If mice are found dead or moribund during the test period, a postmortem examin ation is conducted. The microscopic appearance of the liver and spleen is observed and a section54of the organ tissue excised. Impression smears of the tissues are taken for DFA testing and the remaining tissues are processed for culture and isolation. Discard the mouse caracasses by incineration. Interpretation Y.pestis is easily isolated when passaged through susceptible, laboratory raised, specific pathogen free mice. Inoculated mice typically become moribund within first 3 to 4 days post inoculation and ultimately die from disseminated infection. Spleen and liver are enlarged, hemolytic and sometimes contain multiple focal abcesses. Tissue samples taken from the mice are a good source of nearly pure Y. pestis culture. If mice do not yield and infective i solate, indirect evidence of Y.pestis infection may be obtained by testing the serum of surviving mice for antibodies to Y.pestis. Mouse morbidity/mortality plus DFA positive liver or spleen tissue are presumptive evidence for plague. Quality Control Mouse handling conditions must comply with local animal ethical committee guidelines. Since the mouse inoculation test is dependent on visible morbidity and mortality as the outcome, mouse colonies should be inoculated with known virulent. Y.pestis to test th eir sensitivity to infection prior to use. 5.6.4.5Specific Bacteriophage Lysis Test Bacteriophage typing of bacteria is a common method by which bacteria are identified, grouped or sub-typed. Y.pestis cells are sensitive to lysis by temperature specific bacteriophage; thus, this feature can be used to confirm its identification. Plague bacteria are susceptible to bacteriophage lysis at 20 -250C and 370C. Y.psuedotuberculosis may be differentiated from Y.pestis by the loss of lysis at incubation temperature s of less than 280C. The bacteriophage lysis test should be performed on a pure or nearly pure culture to confirm the presence of the plague bacilli. Enriched medium like 6% SBA, is preferred for use in the test since Y.pestis grows slower on standard med ia(nutrient agar (NA), trypticase soy agar or BHI agar). The test described here uses a bacteriophage impregnated filter paper strip as the test reagents. The paper strip method is preferred to the drop method, in which a spot of liquid bacteriophage cult ure is dropped onto a lawn of cells and lysis is visualized by a clear zone where the bacteriophage was placed. Depending on the seeding concentration of the lawn of cells, spot -lysis results may not be sharply distinguishable. Procedure Duplicate SBA or NA plates should be inoculated with thin (<5 -mm width) parallel lines of test cultures. Up to a total of 8 lines may be placed on the agar surface with the last two lines to contain the control cultures, Y.pestis A1122 and Y.p seudotuberculosis. Place a bac teriophage -impregnated paper strip perpendicular to the lines of culture. Gently tap the paper strip onto the agar surface so that full contact is made. Tape to seal the plates. Incubate one plate at 20 -250C ( this is usually the same ambient room temperature), and the other plate at 370C for 18-24 hours.55Observe for lysis at the area where the bacteriophage paper strip intersects the culture line. Decontaminate plates by autocalving before discarding. Interpretation Results of lysis may be less obvious at 24 hours when standard media are used; and if the culture was not pure, contaminations may overgrow and mask the lysis. Only Y.pestis cells are lysed by the bacteriophage at both 20 -250C and at 370C. Lysis at both temperature, after 24 hours incubation, i s a confirmatory test for plague; therefore, controls results must also be satisfactory before reporting the results. Prolonged incubation may lead to false interpretation because of the movement of bacteria cells on the filter paper strips, or if using th e drop method, contaminants may overgrow the cleared area and mask lysis activity. Always ensure that the incubator temperatures are set correctly; unsatisfactory results usually are due to improper incubation temperatures. Quality Control The control of Y.pestis and Y.pseudotuberculosis strains must always be used, and the test must be set up for incubation at both temperatures for lysis. If lysis is not working, check for the efficacy of the bacteriophage paper strips, blood plates and incubator temperat ures. Biochemical Test Standard Tube and Rapid Miniaturized Kits is relatively inactive in routine biochemical tests; therefore, biochemical testing is not critical for the identification of plague bacilli. However, some of the tests are useful in differentiating Y.pestis from the other pathogenic Yersinia species (Y.pseudotuberculosis and Y.enterocolitica) and for determining the Y.pestis biotype based on the ability to utilize nitrate and glycerol. When a pure culture is obtained, the biochemic al profile of the suspect Y.pestis culture is generated to complete the culture identification process. Some minor differentiation in sugar fermentations and some enzymatic differences are used to create profile for an isolate. Procedure Pure culture is g rown for 24 hours at 370C in BHI broth or on SBA. A suspension of cells equal to 108cells/ml is made in either diluent or in saline. Each biochemical tube in inoculated with 0.1ml of suspended culture, or inoculated as per manufacturer's instructions. Tub es/kits are incubated at 370C for 24 hours. Reaction to each tube is observed and recorded. At the completion of test, the tubes are decontaminated by autocalving before discarding. The change in the pH indicator and substrates should be recorded and comp ared to known profiles of Y.pestis strains. The biochemical reactivity of plague strains is not very distinctive(Table 5 .1). The unease test may be used to distinguish Y.pestis from the closely related Y.pseudotuberclosis; however, there are rare unease -positive isolates of Y.pestis. Glycerol fermentation and nitrate reduction test d istinguish biotypes (Table 5 .2).56Table 5.1: Biochemical and Test or Y.pestis Y.pseudotuberculosis Catalase Positive Positive Coagulase Positive Positive Indole Negative Negative Oxidase Negative Negative Urease Negative* Positive Adonitol Negative Positive L-Rhamnose Negative Positive Glucose Negative Positive Mannitol Negative Positive Melibiose Variable* Positive Sucrose Negative Negative Negative Ornithine Negative Negative Nitrate Variable* Positive *Indicate the more prominent Y.Pestis + - Antiqua + + Mediaevalis - + Quality Control For tube tests, each batch of medium should be tested with bacterial strains that are known to be positive or negative for the reaction to ensure appropriate reactivity. Check the reactivity of the medium to support growth and acid production by inoculating a tube with Yersinia pestis strain A1122, K.pneumoniae and Esch.coli. Incubate test tubes at 370C for 24-48 hours. Commercial kit ought to be tested with control strains to verify kit performance. If profiles of control strains cannot be properly generated, then the reagents, tube medium or identification kit, and technical problems must be examined and corrected. Antimicrobial Susceptibility Test Prompt diagnosis and ap propriate antimicrobial treatment are important for successful resolution of plague infection. The drugs of choice of treatment of plague are streptomycin or gentamicin. Tetracyclines, sulfonamides and chloramphenicol are also very effective alternative dr ugs for treatment. Penicillins and cephalosproins are not recommended. Penicillins appear effective in inhibiting Y.pestis in vitro; however, this antibiotic is considered ineffective against human disease. Therefore, in vitro antimicrobial test results sh ould be interpreted carefully. Although a multidrug -resistant isolate from Madagascar has been recovered from bubonic plague case, drug resistance has not been a problem in treating plague. Naturally occurring strains of resistant Y.pestis isolates are r are. The potential for the spread and public health implication of multidrug - resistance Y.pestis needs to be monitored by research and heightened surveillance.57The disk diffusion method for determining antimicrobial susceptibility is most commonly used method because of its simplicity. Disk diffusion results are reported as antimicrobial susceptible, intermediate or resistant, based on the size of the zone of inhabitation around the disk. The zone size is inversely proportional to the MIC levels, though M IC (µg/ml antibiotic) cannot be determined by this test. The antibiotic -containing disks are impregnated with a fixed concentration of antimicrobial agent, and these disks are purchased from commercial sources. The limiting factor of the disk diffusion tes t is the dependence on the availability of the variety of drug-impregnated disks. Procedure Prepare inoculums by passing test and control isolates in Brain Heat Infusion (BHI) broth or on Sheep Blood Agar(SBA) and incubate for 24 -48 hours at 370C. Standar by adjusting the turbidity to McFarland turbidity standard 0.5 in 2 -5ml of saline in a 13x100mm sterile test tube. Pre warm Muller Hinton Agar(MHA) plates to ambient room temperature. Moisture on the surface of the plate will affect the test; therefore, ensure that the surface is dry before inoculation. Plates should be inoculated within 15 minutes of inoculum preparation. Vortex to mix the inoculums well. Dip a sterile cotton swab into the suspension; roll the swab several times fi rmly against the wall of the tube(above the liquid level) to remove excess liquid from the swab. Streak the swab over the entire surface of the agar plate 3 times, rotating the plate at 600C each time so that the inoculum is evenly streaked across the entire plate. Run the swab around the agar edge before discarding the swab in an appropriate container for decontamination and disposal. Let the sugar surface adsorb the inoculums for 5 minutes (with lids slightly ajar) before applying antimicrobial disks. Equilibrate the antimicrobial disks to ambient room temperature prior to use. Place the disks evenly on the inoculated agar surface. Keep about 24mm distance between two disks. Disks may be placed with sterile forceps or by using dispensing apparatus. With sterile forceps, gently tap down each disk onto agar surface to prevent slipping. No more than 12 disks should be placed on a 150mm plate and not more than 5 disks on a 100mm plate. Disks should not be moved once they have touched the agar surface since diff usion begins almost immediately upon contact with the agar. Invert and tape plate lid to bottom in two places for safety and incubate at 370C for at least 24 hours. Measure zones of inhibition and record results. Decontaminate plates before discarding. Interpretation The quality of the MHA plate and standardized inoculum are curical for the accuracy of antimicrobial susceptibility test results. Before recording results, ensure that the zones of inhibition are uniform and circular and that the lawn of growt h is even and confluent. Results must be taken at 24 hours; tetracycline and chloramphenicol are bacteriostic; their effect is diminished beyond 24 hours at the levels used and may result in erroneous sensitivity level if measurements are taken too late. M easure the diameters of the zones(including the diameter of the disk) to the nearly whole millimeter with a ruler, sliding caliper or caliberate template. The zone edge measured should be an area where there is no obvious growth to the unaided eye. Small colonies detected by transmitted light or under magnification should not be taken as the edge of confluent growth. Any growth within the zone of inhibition would suggest resistance.58Colonies appearing in the zones should be subcultured and their identity sh ould be verified and retested. The diameters measured should be interpreted based on the guidelines published by the NCCLS. The results are reported as susceptible, intermediate or resistant to the antimicrobial agents tested. Quality Control Each batch o f MHA plates should be tested to ensure accurate performance by assessing diameter zones for standard organisms. These zones must be acceptable. A panel of cultures, Y.pestis strain A1122 (avirulent) and organisms that are susceptible and resistant to the antibiotics selected should be tested on the agar. Care must be given to ensure that the agar is at 4-mm depth; agar too deep may give false resistance results and thinner agar may given false susceptibility results. The pH of the agar must also fall betwe en 7.2-7.4 since pH ranges that are too acidic/basic can adversely affect potency of drugs (gentamicin, which is an aminoglycoside, will lose potency at acidic pH). If the growth on the plate is not confluent, the results should not be taken and the test s hould be repeated. The commercially purchased antimicrobial disks should be stored according to the manufacturer's recommendations and should not be used beyond the expiration dates. Eac h batch of new disks should be tested against the panel of standard organisms to ensure performance. 5.6.4.8Serological Tests Plague serology tests have been based on the detection of antibody to whole cells and to the Y.pestis -specific F1 antigen. The agglutination test is simple to perform, does not depend on a secondary labeled reagent and is not species dependent. Thus , this test has broader applicability in plague surveillance, where antibody detection of many mammalian species can be examined by the same format. In the passive haemagglutination assay(PHA) tes t for plague, F1 antigen is coated onto gluteraldehyde -fixed Sheep Red Blood Cells (SRBCs) and used as the sensitized antigen. Serum, plasma or serum proteins extracted from whole blood dried on filter paper may be used as a source of antibody in the PHA. Nonspecific cross -reactivity may occur in agglutination tests giving rise to indeterminate results. Consequently, two control measures need to be included with the test: 1) Pre -adsorption of the serum with fresh SRBCs to remove non -specific cross - reactivity; and, 2) if the serum sample reacts positively, a F1 inhibitation(PHI) test must also be run to verify the specificity of the agglutination test. Procedure Preparation of serum/plasma test samples Heat-inactive serum/plasma samples at 560C for 30 minute s. Add one drop (50µl) of packed, washed SRBCs to every 0.5ml of test sample. Adsorb for 30-60 minutes at ambient room temperature or overnight at 40C. Centrifuge at 100Xg for 10 minutes to sediment SRBCs; remove clarified test sample to a new vial. Sample is ready for testing. Hold serum/plasma at 40C temporarily until testing is completed.59Setting up the PHA/PHI Plate Screening test (4-wells PHA test). If there are many samples and if there is enough specimen volume for more than one test (at least 200 µl), it may be useful to first screen the samples. Divide the 96 -Well plate horizontally into two sections: top 4 rows and bottom 4 rows(this permits screening 10 samples plus one positive and one negative in each section). Add 25µl of Haemagglutination Di luent (HA) to all wells. To each first well, add 25 µl of serum. Set pipettor to 25 µl and serially dilute the samples through well 4, discard the last 25 µl. Add 25µl of diluted Sensitized Sheep Red Blood Cells(SSRBCs) to all the wells, mix gently and in cubate at ambient room temperature for 4 hours or overnight at 40C. Standard test (8-wells PHA and 4 -wells PHI). Divide the 96 -well plate vertically into two compartments: one section with 8 columns and the other with 4 columns (can test 6 rows of test samples plus one positive and one negative control serum on each plate). End Point of High Titer Specimen On high titred specimen that exceed 8 wells of agglutination. It is recommended that the specimen be retested with 12 or more PHA wells and 12 PHI well s, along with the positive and negative controls. Interpretation Examine the wells for flocculent, lattice -type agglutination. Negative wells will have a sharp edged button or a small, well defined circl e. Screening titer results of 1:10 are considered positive for plague since antibody to F1 antigen is specific. Because of likely nonspecific cross reactivity , all screening test -positive samples must be further tested by full end point dilution and PHI before reporting the final t iter. Agglutination of true positives in the PHI buffer will be inhibited because free F1 antigen in the PHI buffer will react with anti -F1 antibodies and thus remove antibody that can react with the F1 bound to the SRBCs. End point titer are then deter mined by taking the last PHA well showing full agglutination and subtracting from that the PHI wells showing agglutination. The resulting well number represents the end point titer. For example, if the PHA results for a specimen shows full agglutination at 6 wells and the PHI agglutination is at 2 wells then 6 -2=4, the end point titer would be 1:32. Quality Control Each lot of SSRBCs & diluent must be tested with a control serum panel to ascertain that performance does not deviate from pervious lots. For e ach positive sample, care must be taken to achieve an end -point and ensure the specificity of the reaction. Specificity of the reaction must be tested by the PHI test to rule out non -specific reactivity. 5.6.4.9Molecular Techniques Molecular techniques a re powerful tools that can provide information about the etiological agent that cannot be obtained by traditional diagnostic methods. When standard microbiologic methods60fail to yield a viable isolate, molecular -based tests may be the only means available to confirm the presence of Y.pestis Molecular techniques used by the diagnostic laboratory have primarily been for the purpose of grouping isolates to gain more discriminatory power over the traditional biologic typing methods. Reproducibility is influ enced by biological and technical variability; therefore, these techniques in the diagnostic laboratory should be selectively applied. Polymerase Chain Reaction for the detection of selected Yesinia pestis genes PCR methodology has provided exquisite disc riminatory power in detecting low quantities of an infectious agent nucleic acid in a specimen. Because of PCR's theoretical ability to detect a single DNA copy, the use of PCR methodology in a diagnostic laboratory has to be rigorously controlled to preve nt false -positive results . Application This method should be used for reference and experimental purposes. PCR should be used only if cultures cannot be recovered . Procedure For DNA template preparations, DNA extraction kits following manufacturer's guid elines should be used. Recovery from Fresh Culture BHI Broth -Harvest fresh (24 -48 hours) Y.pestis cells from BHI broth. The amount of cells collected should have a turbidity equivalent to OD 6000.2. Pellet cells by centrifugation at 800Xg for 5 minutes on the microfuge. Discard the supernatant broth. SBA plate -Harvest cells using a calibrated 1 µl loop. Transfer a loopful of cells to 100 µl of lysis buffer. Cell pellet should equal to 10 µl volume of packed cells. Resuspend the pellets in 100µl of lysis buffer. Vortex to get an even suspension. Add 1 µl of proteinase K. Vortex again. Incubate the tube at 370C for 1 hour. Heat at 950C for 2 minutes (to inactive proteinase K, and to separate the double standard DNA). Keep tube on ice if ready to use for PCR or store at -200C. DNA templates sometimes may have to be further purified and stored under specific conditions free of inhibitory agents or other impurities. Extract and purify DNA by adding 100 µl(Equal volume) of saturated phenol (pH 8). Vortex brie fly to mix well, then spin in microfuge at 40C(in cold room) at top speed for 3 -5minutes. The contents of the tube should separate to a clear top layer(DNA-containing aqueous phase), a middle layer if dense white pellicle(cell debris), and bottom layer(ph enol). Recovery of DNA Template after Phenol Extraction Transfer the top aqueous layer on a new clean tube; add ether in the chemical hood. Vortex briefly to mix well, discard top layer (ether) and let the tube sit open in the air for 5 minutes to let ether completely evaporate. Add 2.5 volumes of salty ethanol(EtOH) (to 100 µl of extract, add 250µl of salty EtOH), vortex to mix well, then place the tube under one of the following conditions to precipitate and store the DNA.61For Shortest Time: insert tube into dry ice to quick freeze for 5 minutes, This method gives the lowest recovery of DNA. For Moderate Time: Place tube at -700C for 30 minutes For longest Time :Place tube at -200C for 2 hours to overnight. This is the preferred method to collect and s tore DNA. Collect DNA by centrifugation in the microfuge at the top speed for 15 minutes at 40C. Remove all traces if the EtOH. Then add 50µl of Tris -EDTA (TE) buffer (pH 8.0) and mix gently. Template is ready for PCR. To make stocks of reference DNA, a liquot the template(above 50 µl) into 10 µl aliquots in microfuge tubes, then add 2.5 volumes of salty EtOH to tube. Invert to mix tube contents well; then plate at -200C. To use stock, repeat this step and resuspended DNA in 10 µl of TE. Interpretation Amplicon of the expected size would suggest a positive reaction. If the water blank control has a product, this would mean that the PCR run cannot be validated and must be repeated after reagent check and equipment cleansin g have been done. Negative PCR results do not mean a true negative. PCR reactions are sensitive to the balance of template -to-primer ratios and the amount of magnesium or inhibitors present. If one or another component is off -balance, the results will be PCR negative. Each DNA template may need to be titrated to obtain the ideal reaction conditions. Quality Control Aerolisation and carry over of DNA template are the most common PCR problems leading to false positive results. PCR is so sensitive in detecti ng low amount of target DNA template therefore special attention must be given to work flow so that it is unidirectional starting from extraction, assembly, amplification to analysis. Separate physical areas must be dedicated for each work area as well sep arate pipettors set aside for each step. Pipettors used with DNA or primers must use barrier -tips to reduce unwanted DNA transfer. All equipments should be cleaned with 10 percent bleach solution followed by 70% alcohol wash . 5.6.4.10Animal Pathogenicit y test Two animals can be used: Guinea pigs White mice The diagnosis of isolated strain can be confirmed by animal inoculation. The animals are injected subcutaneously with exudate of bubo or with 24 hours growth in broth. Infected animals die within 2-5 days and post mortem shows:63Local necrosis with oedema Enlargement of regional lymph nodes Hepatosplenomegaly Impression smears prepared from heart blood, bone marrow or affected organs shall show presence of bipolar staining organisms. In case of polycontaminated material, injection to guineapigs must be preferred to inoculation of mice due to extreme susceptibility of the mouse to associated pathogens such as pneumococci, anaerobes etc. 5.6.4.11New Rapid Diagnostic Tests ELISA based Rapid Seo logical Tests ELISAs for detecting IgM and IgG antibodies and for antigen capture, are especially useful in laboratory diagnosis in early period of illness. Dot ELISA kit for F1 antibody detection The newly developed Dot ELISA kit for detection of antibod ies to F1 antigen for serosurveillance and possibly for disease diagnosis employs a relatively less amount of F1 antigen and is workable with both the conventionally purified F1 antigen or the recombinant F1 antigen. The kit is fully field based and does n ot require any laboratory equipment for any specialized training. Test can be performed with a drop of blood without the need of serum separation and the results are obtained within 90 minutes. Sandwich Dot ELISA for detection of F1 antigen A sandwich Dot ELISA has been standardized for detection of F1 antigen from the blood following Y. pestis infection. Testing carried out in experimental animals revealed that the antigen detection by the test was comparable to isolation and immunofluorescent test and t his could be promising rapid and simple test for routine adaption by the plague laboratories. Methods for Rapid Identification of Y.pestis and enzyme substrate biochemical kit For rapid presumptive identification of Y.pestis isolates from broth or agar me dia, a simple and convenient to use biochemical system has been developed based on 9 newly identified bacterial enzyme substrate reactions. Results are obtained within 30 minutes to 2 hrs. Moderately contaminated cultures can also been tested with this bio chemical kit without need of purifying the miocroo rganisms. Monoclonal antibody sandwich Dot ELISAs Recombinant membrane of Y.pestis, namely Pia, Vops, VopM, VopV and hmsT that elicited response were produced. Specific mono clonal and the polychonal antibodies generated against these proteins could be successfully utilized in developing sandwich Dot ELISA kits that could provide confirmatory identification of Y.pestis isolates within 2 hrs. All the above mentioned tests need to be evaluated by WHO Collaborative Centres, before these are used for testing of samples and release of reports.645.6.4.12Safety in the Laboratory Handling of Y.pestis or material suspected to be having this organism requires biosafety level II (BSL-II) environment and precautions. However, when large volumes of culture are handled, BSL-III facilities are required. Only trained personnel, in restricted area, should undertake plague diagnostic work. The infectious material must be handled only in biosa fety cabinets (vertical laminar airflow under negative pressure and vented to the outside). In accordance with national or institutional policy, chemoprophylaxis or immunoprophylaxis, with regular monitoring, should be provided to laboratory staff. They m ust wear gowns, gloves (with sleeves of gowns tucked into gloves) and masks (if aerosol generation is expected). Hand washing before leaving the laboratory should be mandatory. A solution of 0.5% sodium hypochlorite should be used to decontaminate the lab oratory surfaces as well as for managing the spills. In later case sodium hypochlorite should be sprayed into spill, left as such for 10 minutes and followed by a 70% alcohol wash. Other germicidal solutions containing phenol or quaternary ammounium compou nds should be used in instances where hypochlorite is considered corrosive. All contaminated material must be placed in highly visible biohazard bags. These should be filled only to two -third capacity, sealed with sterility indicator autoclave tape and au toclaved at 1150C for 15 minutes before disposal. Sharps should be disposal of in rigid puncture -proof containers, labeled with biohazard sign and decontaminated with autoclaving. 5.6 TREATMENT The response of plague to antibiotic treatment in dramatic a nd rapid. Chemotherapy must be started at the earliest suspicion of plague without waiting for laboratory confirmation as it will not only curtail morbidity and prevent mortality but also contribute towards containment of transmission of infection by rende ring the patient noninfectious. Specific drugs recommended for treatment of plague are tetracycline, chloramphenicol, co -trimoxazole, sulphonamide and streptomycin. Penicillin is ineffective. 5.7PREVENTION AND CONTROL METHODS Long-term prevention and c ontrol of plague is primarily based on following activities: Surveillance Rodent control Vector control Chemoprophylaxis Immunoprophylaxis Surveillance Establishing and sustaining an effective surveillance system is a prerequisite for prevention and control of plague. A senior and experience officer should be identified at the district and state level to co -ordinate and supervise surveillance activities. As a first step, it is necessary to identify the natural foci of plague in the country and find out whi ch local rodent and flea species should be targeted for extensive surveillance and control. It is also necessary to know the information on local landscape, human activity and host/vector ecology to design prevention and control strategies appropriate for a particular plague focus. Expertise available at the national level65(NCDC) may be sought for these activities and for training of core people involved in surveillance activities. The surveillance activities should cover surveillance of rodents and vect ors as well as laboratory and clinico -epidemioloical surveillance.It is emphazied that surveillance is not a one - time activity and has to be carried out on a continuos basis to be effective in prevention and control of plague. Rodent Control Rodents are t he most adaptable among all mammals and form the most important reservoirs of infections transmissible to man. As with all wild animals, there is a delicate balance between their number and natural regulatory forces. However, during any disruption within t he environment, rodents are the first to respond and adapt to new circumstances. Rodent species which are synanthorpic (living rattus, R.nervegicus, Mus.musculus, Bandicota bengalensis, B. indica etc. may act as reservoir of disease and play role in the spread and transmission of plague. Rodent control activities should be undertaken during interepidemic period only. Killing of rodent during epidemic situations may result in large number of fleas leaving their dead rodents and biting human beings and transmitting the infection. Rodent control measures should, therefore, always be undertaken as a long -terms measure. Vector Control Flea control measures should be undertaken during following situations : As and when any localit y/area rat fall. Increase in the population of fleas/any area reporting flea nuisance(increase of flea index). Flea (Xenopsylla cheopis) index found to be more than 1.0 through active surveillance in areas of known foci of natural plague. On receipt of spe cific information from local health authorities about flea nuisance and apprehending plague. Chemoprophylaxis Preventive therapy may be taken in the event of exposure to the bites of rodent fleas during an outbreak or to the tissues or fluids of a plague -infected animal, in the event of close exposure to another person or to a pet animal with suspected plague pneumonia. For preventive drug therapy, the preferred antibiotics are the tetracylines, chloramphenicol, or one of the effective sulfonamides. Chemop rophylaxis is given until one week after the exposure ceases. Immunoprophylaxis A formalin killed plague vaccine is produced in limited quantity by Haffkine Institute, Mumbai. It contains 2000 million organisms per ml. Dosage:The adult dose is 0.5ml giv en subcutaneously followed by second dose of 1ml given after 7-14 days. Boosters are given every six months. Immunity appears after 5 -7 days of66complete vaccination and lasts for about six months. Repeated boosters induce higher incidence of adverse reacti ons. Adverse reactions: Vaccination may result in adverse effects of fever, headache, malaise, lymphadenopathy and erythema and indurations at the injection site. These reactions are more common after repeated injections. The vaccine should not be given t o persons with unknown hypersensitivity to beef protein, soya, casein or phenol. Persons with history of severe local or systemic reactions to plague vaccine should not be revaccinated. Vaccine is contraindicated for pregnant women because of its potential risk to produce abortions or fatal abnormalities . Vaccination is of little use during human plague outbreaks, since a month or more is required to develop a protective immune response. Vaccination is recommended only for high risk group of individuals. Medical and public health workers who are dealing with patients of plague or who investigate plague outbreaks. Laboratory workers who handle plague cultures of plague infected materials. It is unlikely that plague vaccine will protect completely a vaccine e xposed to infection from patients with pneumonic plague. Therefore, all persons exposed to patients with suspected pneumonic plague should receive antibiotics regardless of their immunization status. Universal precautions Health workers handling plague ca ses or material infected with plague bacilli should take following precautions: Take chemoprophylaxis with tetracycline or co -trimoxazole mentioned above. Depending upon feasibility, such workers should be immunized with plague vaccine. Handle material sus pected to be contaminated with plague bacilli very carefully. Such material should be incinerated or properly sterilized. A patient with pneumonic plague should be given respiratory isolation or cohorted. All workers coming in contact with patient of pneum onic plague or processing clinical material must wear mask, goggles and gloves and must take all biosafety measures.
